column2: Jove took the infant Bacchus and gave him in charge to the Nysaean nymphs, who nourished his infancy and childhood, and for their care were rewarded by Jupiter by being placed, as the Hyades, among the stars.

column2: When Bacchus grew up he discovered the culture of the vine and the mode of extracting its precious juice; but Juno struck him with madness, and drove him forth a wanderer through various parts of the earth.
column3: When Bacchus grew up he discovered the culture of the vine and the mode of extracting its precious juice; but Juno struck him with madness, and drove him forth a wanderer through various parts of the earth.

column2: In Phrygia the goddess Rhea cured him and taught him her religious rites, and he set out on a progress through Asia, teaching the people the cultivation of the vine.
column3: In Phrygia the goddess Rhea cured him and taught him her religious rites, and he set out on a progress through Asia, teaching the people the cultivation of the vine.

column2: The most famous part of his wanderings is his expedition to India, which is said to have lasted several years.
column3: The most famous part of his wanderings is his expedition to India, which is said to have lasted several years.

column2: Returning in triumph, he undertook to introduce his worship into Greece, but was opposed by some princes, who dreaded its introduction on account of the disorders and madness it brought with it.
column3: Returning in triumph, he undertook to introduce his worship into Greece, but was opposed by some princes, who dreaded its introduction on account of the disorders and madness it brought with it.

column3: As he approached his native city Thebes, Pentheus the king, who had no respect for the new worship, forbade its rites to be performed.

column2: Pentheus, beholding him with wrathful countenance, said, "Fellow! you shall speedily be put to death, that your fate may be a warning to others; but though I grudge the delay of your punishment, speak, tell us who you are, and what are these new rites you presume to celebrate."
column3: Pentheus, beholding him with wrathful countenance, said, "Fellow! you shall speedily be put to death, that your fate may be a warning to others; but though I grudge the delay of your punishment, speak, tell us who you are, and what are these new rites you presume to celebrate."

column2: The prisoner, unterrified, responded, "My name is Acetes; my country is Maeonia; my parents were poor people, who had no fields or flocks to leave me, but they left me their fishing rods and nets and their fisherman's trade.
column3: The prisoner, unterrified, responded, "My name is Acetes; my country is Maeonia; my parents were poor people, who had no fields or flocks to leave me, but they left me their fishing rods and nets and their fisherman's trade.

column2: This I followed for some time, till growing weary of remaining in one place, I learned the pilot's art and how to guide my course by the stars.

column2: It happened as I was sailing for Delos we touched at the island of Dia and went ashore.
column3: It happened as I was sailing for Delos we touched at the island of Dia and went ashore.

column2: Next morning I sent the men for fresh water, and myself mounted the hill to observe the wind; when my men returned bringing with them a prize, as they thought, a boy of delicate appearance, whom they had found asleep.
column3: Next morning I sent the men for fresh water, and myself mounted the hill to observe the wind; when my men returned bringing with them a prize, as they thought, a boy of delicate appearance, whom they had found asleep.

column2: They judged he was a noble youth, perhaps a king's son, and they might get a liberal ransom for him.

column2: There was something in them which I felt sure was more than mortal.
column3: There was something in them which I felt sure was more than mortal.

column2: I said to my men, 'What god there is concealed in that form I know not, but some one there certainly is.

column2: Pardon us, gentle deity, for the violence we have done you, and give success to our undertakings.' So blind is the lust of gain!

column2: 'This ship shall not be profaned by such impiety,' said I. 'I have a greater share in her than any of you.' But Lycabas, a turbulent fellow, seized me by the throat and attempted to throw me overboard, and I scarcely saved myself by clinging to the ropes.

column2: Where are you going to carry me?' One of them replied, 'Fear nothing; tell us where you wish to go and we will take you there.' 'Naxos is my home,' said Bacchus; 'take me there and you shall be well rewarded.' They promised so to do, and told me to pilot the ship to Naxos.
column3: Where are you going to carry me?' One of them replied, 'Fear nothing; tell us where you wish to go and we will take you there.' 'Naxos is my home,' said Bacchus; 'take me there and you shall be well rewarded.' They promised so to do, and told me to pilot the ship to Naxos.

column2: Naxos lay to the right, and I was trimming the sails to carry us there, when some by signs and others by whispers signified to me their will that I should sail in the opposite direction, and take the boy to Egypt to sell him for a slave.
column3: Naxos lay to the right, and I was trimming the sails to carry us there, when some by signs and others by whispers signified to me their will that I should sail in the opposite direction, and take the boy to Egypt to sell him for a slave.

column2: I was confounded and said, 'Let some one else pilot the ship;' withdrawing myself from any further agency in their wickedness.
column3: I was confounded and said, 'Let some one else pilot the ship;' withdrawing myself from any further agency in their wickedness.

column2: They cursed me, and one of them, exclaiming, 'Don't flatter yourself that we depend on you for our safety;' took any place as pilot, and bore away from Naxos.
column3: They cursed me, and one of them, exclaiming, 'Don't flatter yourself that we depend on you for our safety;' took any place as pilot, and bore away from Naxos.

column2: Then the god, pretending that he had just become aware of their treachery, looked out over the sea and said in a voice of weeping, 'Sailors, these are not the shores you promised to take me to; yonder island is not my home. column2: It is small glory you will gain by cheating a poor boy.' I wept to hear him, but the crew laughed at both of us, and sped the vessel fast over the sea.

column2: All at once--strange as it may seem, it is true,--the vessel stopped, in the mid sea, as fast as if it was fixed on the ground.
column3: All at once-strange as it may seem, it is true,--the vessel stopped, in the mid sea, as fast as if it was fixed on the ground.

column2: The men, astonished, pulled at their oars, and spread more sail, trying to make progress by the aid of both, but all in vain.
column3: The men, astonished, pulled at their oars, and spread more sail, trying to make progress by the aid of both, but all in vain.

column2: ARIADNE
column3: ARIADNE

column2: We have seen in the story of Theseus how Ariadne, the daughter of King Minos, after helping Theseus to escape from the labyrinth, was carried by him to the island of Naxos and was left there asleep, while the ungrateful Theseus pursued his way home without her.
column3: We have seen in the story of Theseus how Ariadne, the daughter of King Minos, after helping Theseus to escape from the labyrinth, was carried by him to the island of Naxos and was left there asleep, while the ungrateful Theseus pursued his way home without her.

column2: Ariadne, on waking and finding herself deserted, abandoned herself to grief.
column3: Ariadne, on waking and finding herself deserted, abandoned herself to grief.

column2: But Venus took pity on her, and consoled her with the promise that she should have an immortal lover, instead of the mortal one she had lost.
column3: But Venus took pity on her, and consoled her with the promise that she should have an immortal lover, instead of the mortal one she had lost.

column2: The island where Ariadne was left was the favorite island of Bacchus, the same that he wished the Tyrrhenian mariners to carry him to, when they so treacherously attempted to make prize of him. As Ariadne sat lamenting her fate, Bacchus found her, consoled her, and made her his wife.
column3: The island where Ariadne was left was the favorite island of Bacchus, the same that he wished the Tyrrhenian mariners to carry him to, when they so treacherously attempted to make prize of him. As Ariadne sat lamenting her fate, Bacchus found her, consoled her, and made her his wife.

column2: As a marriage present he gave her a golden crown, enriched with gems, and when she died, he took her crown and threw it up into the sky.
column3: As a marriage present he gave her a golden crown, enriched with gems, and when she died, he took her crown and threw it up into the sky.

column2: As it mounted the gems grew brighter and were turned into stars, and preserving its form Ariadne's crown remains fixed in the heavens as a constellation, between the kneeling Hercules and the man who holds the serpent.
column3: As it mounted the gems grew brighter and were turned into stars, and preserving its form Ariadne's crown remains fixed in the heavens as a constellation, between the kneeling Hercules and the man who holds the serpent.

column2: Spenser alludes to Ariadne's crown, though he has made some mistakes in his mythology.
column3: Spenser alludes to Ariadne's crown, though he has made some mistakes in his mythology.

column2: It was at the wedding of Pirithous, and not Theseus, that the Centaurs and Lapithae quarrelled.
column3: It was at the wedding of Pirithous, and not Theseus, that the Centaurs and Lapithae quarrelled.

column2: Look how the crown which Ariadne wore Upon her ivory forehead that same day That Theseus her unto his bridal bore, Then the bold Centaurs made that bloody fray With the fierce Lapiths which did them dismay; Being now placed in the firmament, Through the bright heaven doth her beams display, And is unto the stars an ornament, Which round about her move in order excellent.
column3: Look how the crown which Ariadne wore Upon her ivory forehead that same day That Theseus her unto his bridal bore, Then the bold Centaurs made that bloody fray With the fierce Lapiths which did them dismay; Being now placed in the firmament, Through the bright heaven doth her beams display, And is unto the stars an ornament, Which round about her move in order excellent.
